sections.title: Srilankan Wildlife
sections.content: Sri Lanka is second to none in terms of its biodiversity and can be considered the best for big game safaris outside the African continent. As bold a statement as that may be, Sri Lanka's wildlife credentials speak for itself.

sections.title: SRI LANKAN JUNGLEFOWL
sections.description: The Sri Lankan junglefowl (Gallus lafayettii) is a member of the Galliformes bird order which is endemic to Sri Lanka, where it is the national bird. It is closely related to the Red junglefowl from which the chicken was domesticated.
facts: The male Sri Lankan junglefowl is much larger than the female
It has more vivid plumage and a highly exaggerated wattle and comb
The male has orange-red body plumage and dark purple to black wings and tail
The feathers of the mane descending from head to base of the spine are golden
The face has bare red skin and wattles
The comb is red with a yellow center

sections.title: PURPLE-FACED LANGUR
sections.description: The purple-faced langur (Semnopithecus vetulus), also known as the purple-faced leaf monkey, is a species of Old World monkey that is endemic to Sri Lanka.
facts: The animal is a long-tailed arboreal species
Identified by a mostly brown appearance

sections.title: SRI LANKAN LEOPARD
sections.description: The Sri Lankan leopard (Panthera pardus kotiya) is a leopard subspecies native to Sri Lanka. It was first described in 1956 by Sri Lankan zoologist Paules Edward Pieris Deraniyagala.
sections.description2: The Sri Lankan leopard has a tawny or rusty yellow coat with dark spots and close-set rosettes, which are smaller than in Indian leopards. The Sri Lankan leopard has allegedly evolved to become a rather large leopard subspecies, because it is an apex predator without competition by other large wild cat species in the country.
